title: Analysis of Interactions of Salmonella Type Three Secretion Mutants with 3-D Intestinal Epithelial Cells
background: Current understanding of Salmonella pathogenesis is based primarily on monolayer cell cultures, which lack the three-dimensional architecture and differentiation of human intestinal tissue. The prevailing paradigm states that Salmonella Pathogenicity Island-1 Type Three Secretion System (SPI-1 T3SS) is required for bacterial invasion into intestinal epithelium, but this conflicts with clinical observations of SPI-1 deficient strains causing human disease.
objective: To elucidate the role of all characterized Salmonella enterica T3SSs using a physiologically relevant 3-D organotypic model of human intestinal epithelium that better mimics in vivo conditions.
methods: Utilized Rotating-Wall Vessel (RWV) bioreactor system to generate 3-D intestinal epithelial aggregates from HT-29 cells. Infected with wildtype and multiple T3SS mutants (SPI-1, SPI-2, SPI-1/2 double mutant, and SPI-1/2:flhDC triple mutant). Assessed invasion, intracellular growth, and host cell targeting using gentamicin protection assays, confocal microscopy, and immunofluorescence staining.
results: Salmonella invaded 3-D intestinal cells independently of all known T3SSs, with mutants showing similar invasion levels to wildtype. Invasion was an active bacterial process, as non-invasive strains and heat-killed bacteria did not invade. T3SSs were required for substantial intracellular replication. No preferential targeting of specific intestinal cell types (M-cells, enterocytes, Paneth cells) was observed.
conclusion: T3SSs are dispensable for Salmonella invasion into highly differentiated 3-D human intestinal epithelial cells but are required for intracellular bacterial growth, paralleling in vivo infection observations and demonstrating the utility of 3-D models in predicting pathogenic mechanisms.

learning_notes.note: The Rotating-Wall Vessel (RWV) bioreactor creates physiological low fluid shear environments that allow cells to form 3D aggregates with in vivo-like characteristics, including proper polarization, tight junctions, mucus production, and multiple cell types. This system mimics aspects of microgravity and provides more relevant models than traditional 2D cultures for space microbiology research.

Salmonella mutants lacking all known Type Three Secretion Systems (SPI-1, SPI-2, and flagellar T3SS) still invaded 3D intestinal cells at levels similar to wildtype, challenging the prevailing paradigm that SPI-1 T3SS is essential for epithelial invasion. This finding aligns with clinical observations of SPI-1 deficient strains causing human disease.

While T3SSs were dispensable for invasion, they were essential for substantial intracellular replication, as all T3SS mutants showed significantly reduced growth compared to wildtype Salmonella inside 3D intestinal cells, demonstrating the distinct roles of these systems in different stages of infection.

The 3D intestinal model contained multiple epithelial cell types found in human colon, including M-cells/M-like cells, enterocytes, and Paneth cells, providing a physiologically complex environment for studying host-pathogen interactions that better represents actual human tissue architecture.

Invasion into 3D cells was an active bacterial process, as non-invasive bacterial strains (E. coli, B. subtilis), bacterial-sized beads, and heat-killed Salmonella did not invade, indicating specific Salmonella mechanisms beyond passive cellular uptake are responsible for entry.

No preferential targeting of specific intestinal cell types was observed for wildtype or T3SS mutants, with bacteria distributed among M-cells (20-25%), enterocytes (majority), and Paneth cells (<10%), suggesting broad epithelial tropism independent of T3SS function.

This research was funded by NASA grants NNJ06HE92 and NNX09AH40G, indicating direct relevance to spaceflight applications and the importance of developing advanced tissue models for studying host-pathogen interactions under space-relevant conditions.
